avalancheActivity.comment: As a consequence of the strong westerly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed during the last two days. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2000 m. The wind slabs have formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. The avalanches can in isolated cases reach large size. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The current avalanche situation calls for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.

snowpackStructure.comment: 15 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1800 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

avalancheActivity.comment: As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, easily released wind slabs formed in the last two days. The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2200 m. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
avalancheActivity.highlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.

snowpackStructure.comment:
5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 1600 m. The westerly wind has transported the new snow.
Up to 1900 m rain has fallen over a wide area.
In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from westerly directions, mostly small wind slabs formed in the last two days. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2400 m. More recent wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence.

Up to 2100 m rain has fallen over a wide area. In many places there is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Slab avalanches are possible in isolated cases as before.

snowpackStructure.comment:
5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. The westerly wind has transported the new snow.

In all altitude zones only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

avalancheActivity.comment: As a consequence of a strong wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in the last few days at elevated altitudes. The fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases in particular on north to northeast to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in very steep terrain. As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural avalanche activity will appreciably decrease.
avalancheActivity.highlights: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

snowpackStructure.comment:
The snowpack is largely stable and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies in particular below approximately 2400 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
